metadata.source: IRS guidance, Congressional legislation tracker, tax court dockets
metadata.note: Edit to update signal statuses. Push to trigger rebuild.

friction_label: Every USDC-to-USD conversion is a taxable event

signals.signal: IRS treats regulated stablecoins as cash equivalent
signals.note: No IRS guidance issued. GENIUS Act does not address tax treatment.

signals.signal: Legislation exempting USDC-USD from capital gains
signals.note: No bill introduced as of Feb 2026

signals.signal: De minimis exemption for stablecoin transactions
signals.note: A $200 de minimis exemption for crypto was proposed in prior sessions but not enacted

signals.signal: IRS accepts stablecoin for tax payments
signals.note: No indication this is being considered

timeline.event: IRS Notice 2014-21: Virtual currency is property for tax purposes
timeline.impact: All crypto transactions including stablecoin conversions are taxable events

timeline.event: IRS Revenue Ruling 2019-24: Hard forks and airdrops are taxable income
timeline.impact: Reinforced property treatment of all digital assets

timeline.event: Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act: crypto broker reporting requirements
timeline.impact: 1099 reporting required for crypto transactions starting 2025

timeline.event: IRS finalizes digital asset broker reporting rules
timeline.impact: Exchanges must report stablecoin transactions on Form 1099-DA

timeline.event: Form 1099-DA reporting begins for 2025 tax year
timeline.impact: Every stablecoin conversion now reported to IRS

timeline.event: GENIUS Act signed — does NOT address tax treatment
timeline.impact: Regulatory clarity for issuers but tax friction remains for users

note: Tax treatment is potentially the single most important signal. You can have merchant acceptance, payroll, and bank custody — but if every USDC-to-USD conversion triggers a Form 8949 entry, mass consumer adoption is blocked.
